I think light truly is only a wave, but the energy of photons given how long these waves have been around have evolved to a threshold of least resistance causing these wavelengths to cluster up at the point of least resistance making them appear to be particles when they hit a surface due to their innate nature to want to avoid collisions. Due to the fact that since photons are the oldest thing in the universe most of the earlier electromagnetic forces that existed within photons that were prone to colliding with other wavelengths would have over time been eliminated leaving behind the most elusive wavelength in the observable Universe. I feel as if “particles” have their own evolutionary paths like everything else in the Universe. Due to the fact that energy takes the path of least resistance. Thus, only light that is observable can be seen. Within a given time reference or “vertical” you can only see the photons wavelength that is nearest to the observation. Thus all the other information no longer exist in that frame of reference, or point in time. I don’t believe in the cat experiment, not per say. However I do believe that given the fact that light was likely emitted first during the Big Bang that there might be “holograms” that do actually exist in other frames of references where the observation of the missing wavelengths really did occur. However, I think from any given frame of reference one could only conclude that the consciousness of the observers other then themselves can only be a distorted version of themselves. Whether  or not the parallel universes were real or not couldn’t be determined. However I think that theoretically one day through the process of elimination we can eventually come up with a working probability distribution that at the very least can make this appear very probable. I don’t think we can prove it without a doubt, but I think that by comparing the microscopic with the macroscopic that we can rule out most other possibilities. From our frame of reference, given the vertical axis that our system likely exist on, the data that we could get describing other planes of existence would be skewed, and stretched. Even at maximum efficiency in computation. At the best and most rational, I think that we could conclude that they are stretched versions of our reality. It would be difficult to prove that they are more then just illusions created by the warping of the information we would see when observing the photons that hit our plane of existence. Thus, as we observe further and further away from the data that can be gathered within our system the probability distribution would become more and more inaccurate over time.

Classical wave mechanics, and classical particle mechanics don't work. The 2 slit experiment is an example that they don't work. There is no particle wave duality or wave function collapse. or interference. Those are hodgepodges of rules of obsolete classical understandings shoehorned on a quantum mechanical phenomenon . Finding rules phenomena have in common is what science does. For example the rules electricity, magnetism, and light were discovered to have are in common.  It is a clue to new rules when rules don't work with phenomena they should. The rules of wave mechanics don't work when there is one slit open. The rules of particles don't work when there are 2 slits open.  The exact same rules work for either case when we use the rules of quantum mechanics.  The key rule the 2 slit reveals is that when you have 2 or more paths you add "probability amplitudes". which are just arrows that turn like hands on a clock very fast, and stop depending on the time light takes to go those paths. When there's one slit open there is only 1 arrow. When 2 slits open there are 2 arrows. Any path to any point on the screen where the arrows point in mostly the same direction has a band of light, any path to any point where they point in opposite directions there is no light. Simple as that. Goofy as that.

Ok a photon has two parts the storage like a hard drive (the wave part of a photon) that carries the information (the particle part of a photon) of the object that emitted it or reflected it or observed it fully (which full absorbtion is no photon  reflected back or photon empty of information reflected back equals black) so a photon leaving the source that emitted it is a wave with the information (particle) of the source it came from when that photon is reflected by on object part or most of the information from the source is transfered into the object and the photon reflected has a percentage of source information that is 49% or less and  now has 51% or more information from the object reflecting it. So in the double slit experiment the method used to observe the photon shot before the impact of the back wall takes part or most of the information in it away which takes away the interference pattern and when the method used to observe the photon a second time replaces the information the first observance took out and now you get your interference wave pattern again.

It's barely mentioned in the comments of this video, but if you conduct this same experiment with a gun that shoots single particles instead of having a steady wavelike stream flowing from a continuous light source, you STILL GET THE SAME INTERFERENCE PATTERN!!!  A single particle behaves in wavelike manner, passes through both slits by virtue of it traveling along all possible paths simultaneously, interferes with itself, and as you send through more and more, marking the spot where the single particle eventually lands, it creates the interference pattern!  And that's not even the craziest part!  If you were to take some kind of detector or measurement device in an effort to determine which specific slit the particle travels through, the interference pattern disappears, and you're left with a pattern of just two bands, as if a stream of particles just passed through the slits like a ball rather than with the wavelike action.  The energy used by the detector to measure the position of the particle interrupts the wavelike action, making it instead behave like a singular particle.  THEY BEHAVE DIFFERENTLY WHETHER OR NOT THEY'RE BEING OBSERVED!!!  Now this is something reserved specifically for occurences at the quantum level, not affecting the macro scale on which we live, so particles seem to have discrete and singular positions in our everyday occurence.  However, on the scale of atomic action, things just behave differently.

Answer to the last question - As slit is of very smaller dimension (comparable to wavlength of light) wave nature of light dominates, and deviate from their original path . Wave proceeds in the perpendicular direction of wavefronts and every point on wave front is a source of new wavefront called secondary wavefront. When wavefronts pass through the slit it generates secondary wavefronts. Superposition of two secondary wavefronts is obtained at the screen. Thats why they appear as round blobs.

I'm no scientist, just a humble linguist, but here - for what it's worth - is my layperson's attempt to explain this apparent wave-particle duality with common sense and logic (plus a tiny bit of grade-school level physics): suppose that the change of state from wave to particle in the presence of the detector had absolutely nothing to do, as seems to be widely supposed, with human consciousness (let's be honest - a pretty far-fetched explanation!) but were due simply to some kind of physical interaction between the detector (when switched on) and the particle. What if the detector, in the process of observing the particle, were ever so slightly slowing it down, i.e. robbing it of energy in essentially the same way that a freezer robs liquid water of energy and turns it into ice? And what if this (albeit, comparatively minute) loss of energy were just sufficient to turn the wave (analogous to the macrocosmic fluid state) into a particle (analogous to the macrocosmic solid state)? Has anyone ever actually conducted an experiment that would definitively rule this explanation out? And if not, given that it's potentially such a ridiculously simple way of accounting for what happens, isn't it about time that someone did??

Answer to rounded / ovalesque shape:

Also surface interaction is involved, in the corners of the slits, this surface action is from two sides, so the strengths of the surface electromagnetic force imparted by molecules at the edges deflecting the ray becomes stronger, thus both pushing inwards on the projection wall as well as pulling / drawing outwards. And that causes thus a curve like effect, similar to an outswinger vs inswinger in cricket. On of those two swings may dominate plus the deflection in one direction adds to intensity whereas therefore the opposite swing effect, will be to the lessening intensity / density.

The very same surface interaction is responsible for the separation or dispersion into colors.

So also the thicker the edges are, the more dispersion. What one can conclude is that the surface interaction from the edges deflect or push more away, so inwards to the array direction, than pull towards the edge, drawing outwards. It bounces back, the outer parts of the bundle falling through.

So to summarize, it is all about Love dominating, the law of attraction, that thus pushes or bounces off as soon as things get to close. In the corners the Love is stronger, that is why to go for the edges to work the G spot

Regarding the double-slit experiment showing that an electron can seemingly behave as both a particle and a wave, does the experiement record a precise quantifiable amount, and rate, of electrons that are “shot out” towards the two slits? This factor could seem to hold a great deal of importance as to the end result of the expirement, and I will give an analogy to try and explain why; to the human eye, a rotating fan looks as if the fan blades occupy the entire circumfrence of the circular perimeter that which the fan blades are possibly able to move. However, by observing the fan blades when the fan is “off”, or not in rotation, we know that the fan blades only cover a portion of the total area that is perceived to be occupied when the fan blades are in rotation. Using this analogy, isn’t it possible that the entire path taken by a given electron that is being “ejected” and flung towards either one of the two slits in the double-slit experiment, as well as all of the possible paths that an electron could take, could be perceived by the detection equipment, or the “space” in the electron’s path, to be filled with the electron at all times if the conductors of the expirement were “shooting” the electrons out at a fast enough rate, which would cause the resulting pattern on the impact wall to look as if there was indeed some sort of wave interference as a result of both slits being filled with the electron (as the results conclude)?

The reason it showed a cascade of dots and not two single dots\slits:
Because you were observing the light, it was acting as a wave. the higgs boson is resposible for the effect where when unobserved (where if you place a piece of photo paper in the box, and close the viewing port, thus not observing it) and then develop the photo paper result, it should display traits of a particle, due to the fact that it is not being observed during the measurment\recording. (at least i think thats how it works, its been a long time since i studied light waves and the higgs boson aka god particle\CERN, so i might have mixed up details on how to run the experiment in non-observating mode, but apparently even watching it with a video camera caused it to act like a wave as shown in the video, and only by "not intending to observe it at all" were they able to record light acting as a particle, and showing only two dots/slits) i also beleive that they were using pinholes the size of atoms, and an electron beam firing only a single wavelength of light, instead of an organic "messy" light source such as the sun.

Why do we see round blobs?  -  If light got into the box through a pin hole, you would not see a pin-prick of light in the box, but a picture of the sun, which would be round, and would even show details such as sun spots.  Look up "Pin hole camera".  If there was a single slit, that's like a long row of pin holes, so you would expect to see a row of overlapping circular pictures of the sun - an oval blob.

All the electrical signals from our eyes and ears are interpreted by the brain and displayed in our mind's eye as color and sound. Both of these things are merely waves of electromagnetism and vibrations in the air.

Back in my high school days, our physics teacher taught a lab where each pair of students got a microscope slide painted with ink and a pair of scratches. We could estimate the scratch separation by comparing to a plastic mm marked ruler under a microscope; and then, by viewing a pair of incandescent lamps about 10m away, we could find angular separations where fringes lined up through colored plastic filters over our inked and scratched slides simply held up to our eyes. We were all able to estimate and compare wavelengths for different colors of light. Simple and convincing, yet truly astonishing.

Not directly related, but I've seen a Chinese crime drama which made a really clever use of the interference phenomenon, though with sound. Basically, someone had been shot dead in a room, but the police thought the 3 witnesses who came forward were lying, because the one who heard the loudest gunshot was actually the furthest away from the room, while the one nearest to it didn't hear it at all. When the investigation team called in a science professor to find out why, he saw that the room had two windows open and immediately realized what was happening -- Destructive interference had canceled out the sound of the gunshot where the nearest witness was, while constructive interference had reinforced the sound where the furthest witness was so he heard the loudest gunshot.

When is someone going to realize that the material you have slits cut into has dimension. Some of the incoming light hits the sides of the slit and, angle of incidence equals angle of refraction. So the places where that light reflected off the sides of the slit at an angle that caused the light to either bounce back toward the source or bounce back and forth within the slit until losing so much energy that the wave collapses, this second option is the more likely one. This "wasted" light never reaches the screen, thus giving us the dark spots. The lit spots also are a result of these same mechanics. As for why the light appears to be a circle inside the box, it's actually an elongated cylinder with a half circle on each end, due to the fact that the light is also reflecting off the top and directly into the corners of the slits themselves.... So in conclusion, the interference pattern we see is the direct result of one simple fact not taken into account in any single or double slit experiments that I have ever seen.. the material we are using to create the slits is 3 dimensional and the walls of the slit itself are the reason for the interference.

This is very clear to me. light waves are really really short, so to do this experiment one would need a 2 dimensional substance to create the slits, then you would see two slits of light inside the box. What you do is truly amazing, and I love to follow your videos, and I totally envy you for having had access to Young's original notes on the experiment.
Only critic I have is that by no means Young's double slit experiment was decisive in the debate about the nature of light, and that after that the whole scientific community woke up next morning believing light was a wave. It actually continued to be a minoritary view until at least the mid 1820s, and it was not before Young, Arago and Fresnel had (painfully) come to the conclusion (because of several new properties of light related to the phenomenon of polarization) that light had to be a TRANSVERSE wave, rather than longitudinal, as Young first supposed (his studies with light started with his analogy between light and sound), that some of the still troubling aspects of the undulatory explanations (for example the DARK central spot in Newton's rings, where all the interference should be constructive) were finally sorted out and it became (for the time being) the new paradigm in optics. The story of this paradigmatic shift is indeed a gorgeous chapter in the history of physics, and one that triggered the whole deconstruction of "newtonian" (actually laplacian) worldview and paved the way to new sets of theories not (at least fully) based on mechanics: heat, energy, electromagnetism (which eventually would encompass optics) and so on.

I think this dual nature of light as both wave and particle is incorrect.

The double slit experiment will eventually show an interference pattern even when light is only passing through the slits one photon at a time. With only one photon at a time passing through, there should be no interference assuming enough time has passed between photons.

The fact that we still see an interference pattern should be an indication that it is not light acting as a wave, but as a particle traveling along a wave.

The particles of light show us the presence of a wave in the same way that grains of salt show us the interference pattern of sound waves traveling through a plate. Search "amazing resonance experiment" for examples.

As far as I know, color being defined as different wavelengths of light is the only other evidence we have that light is a wave. But if you consider that spacetime is the wavelength being changed in the presence of matter and particles of light are merely traveling along the wave function of spacetime, we no longer need this paradoxical dual state of light as both wave and particle.

If light was a wave, then this same experiment would work with a laser, right? Wrong. It doesn't. So light is not a wave. And it is not an electro-magnetic wave. Magnetism is not affected by glass or by water. When you put a straight stick into a glass of water, it looks bent. The light from the stick is bent by the water and the glass. If light was any type of magnetic wave, the stick would look straight. Also, you can see a single light photon. It's been done, that is a fact. In nature, there is no such thing as a part of a wave. It is either a wave or it is not. The shortest energetic wave is a gamma wave. The longest light photon is only 40% of the length of a  gamma wave. To see a single light photon would mean that you have part of a wave. But there is no such thing. That proves that light is nothing more than a stream of photons. And what makes the different colors, is that photons have different sizes and strengths. The stronger and larger of the photon, the more capable it is of passing through various resistances. Because this experiment does not use a laser, the light is not coming from a single direction. If you think it is, then you are not realising the strength and minuteness of light. So when the light is reflected off of the sides of the holes, (and because it is not a laser, it is reflecting) then the stronger and weaker photons are separated and are causing the rainbow.

Your demonstration of water waves cancelling themselves is about the best I've seen. But the notion that photons/electrons/neutrinos have anything to do with it is hogwash. It's actually a stumbling block in our journey to find a better understanding of light. Light, by the way, is ONLY comprised of electromagnetic waves.. And human eyes can not see particles like photons/electrons/neutrinos. Our retinas can only perceive EM waves. Photons DO INDEED create electromagnetic light when they smash into atoms.  That collision causes a reaction which creates electromagnetic waves (Of a yet unknown form of energy) which then eminate (as a certain frequency) in all possible paths away from the reaction point. It's why our sky appears blue to us. Because the atoms and molecules in a certain layer of our atmosphere tend to absorb all other colors but light blue when photons smash into them. The photon did not create the light blue waves. And neither did the atoms.  The atoms merely rejected the light blue frequency and allowed it to pass.  Ergo the light blue waves travel to the very spot on Earth you are standing at. But also in all other directions including outward and away from Earth. Why then can't Astronauts see the "blue" when they rise above that layer in the atmosphere?  Because they are ELECTRO-MAGNETIC waves. The answer is in their name. They are attracted to the Earth's opposite electromagnetic construct, some call it the Earth's magnetic field. I call it gravity. And I believe gravity is caused by the very photons that crash into other material things to produce light (remember, light = EM waves, not particles.)  Though I prefer to call them neutrinos because I think they have a dual changing prooerty: Charged positive or negative. The chemical reaction of stars cause a positive charge (Of a yet unknown energy). When that positive neutrino strikes other physical matter a reaction occurs that creates EM waves which humans can see. And the now negative neutrino travels on into the earth, a concentrated bulk of matter which accepts the negative charge like a huge negatively charged capacitor.  That huge capacitor "Earth"  then attracts more positive neutrinos and also attracts  the positively charged EM waves.  It's really a lot more complicated than this. What I've explained is analogous to your pond demonstration. In short light is positive EM energy moving through the ether in frequencies. They travel in all directions but can be pulled off any single course by a more powerful negative EM source.  And gravity is negative EM capacitance.  Very simple. Photons are neutrinos there charged negatively or positively and particulate matter. They leave stars positively charged and lose their positive charge when colliding with other physical matter. During that collision the positive charge transforms into positively charged EM waves. Positive photons traveling through space can also be pulled off course by more powerfully negatively charged capacitive bodies of mass like planets. In fact I'd venture to say that most phones emanating from other stars rarely reach the Earth. But the EM waves those photons created millions of light years away do reach us in the form of twinkling stats.  The Sun's photons however showed us unobstructed. Finally, the fact that positive EM waves can be slowed or detoured by intervening planetary capacitance before reaching us implies that the speed of light is not a constant, but varies with the different turbulences it might encounter on the way too us.  For example, the EM waves from a star in the NW sky might have passed nearby 100 strong negatively charged planets on its course to reach us, giving it a higher drag factor than EM waves from a different night star whose EM waves passed nearby only 10 negatively charged planets on its path to reach us.  The 2 different speeds of light would not be the same. They can't be the same. Ergo the speed of light is not a single constant speed for all light.   E = MC squared is therefore variating.  It would be helpful for we humans to think of it as the speed of ElectroMagnetic waves instead of "light." Because "light" is severely misunderstood. However since photons also suffer from the same drag factor that EM waves suffer from as they pass negatively charged bodies it wouldnt make a difference if we continued to believe that light is comprised of any way of particles. Which begs the question- why would any one think the speed of light is a constant? We've known for more than a century that planets can change and affect the speed and paths of light. That's still true regardless if light is EM waves, particles, or both.

Seemingly obvious if one does not know what is actually going on. That is about to be changed by a few fellows, Herman Haus, John J. Farrell and Randell Mills. They looked at this experiment very closely. The result of that investigation Is that it is not about waves and also not about particles. It is something else all together. It is the resonance of the electrons on the outer part of the atoms on the edges of those slits, with what is going through the slits, be that light or electrons or something else. That resonance builds up a charge currents in the material of the slits, which in turn sets up a series of energetic nodes between the slits. The nodes redirect the light going through the slits to the screen, called the far field. That is how the resonance set up by the slits determines that pattern, and not how the light itself is constituted as a wave or a particle. That was a way of looking at the experiment that used only the effect caused by the light itself, without looking at effect that the slits had on what was going through the slits. That explanation was actually predicted by a Quantum Mechanical theory that was developed by those fellows, between 1986 and 1990 and which theory is being further derived currently. The theory that uses waves has had a very hard time of getting anything useful, like a device to be developed, when using the guidance of the wave based theory. Fusion and q-bits are very complicated to explain and impossible to develop using waves. Using the other theory everything becomes much more simplified. Because of that, much simpler way of doing things, at the quantum scale, have been used to develop 3 or 4 different things in a very short time, that all work exactly as predicted by that new theory and do things that the wave based theory cannot be used, to make those kinds of things. One is a molecular modeller that can construct models of atoms that are almost as perfect as are the real atoms whose parameters are found by analytical methods. The modellers using the math of wave based QM can only model the Hydrogen atom with the same degree of accuracy. Anything else, even the next atom in the periodic table, the helium atom, when modelled by wave based math, has its parameters so far off the real atom's as to be about a hundred percent off in that accuracy.
Another prediction of the new theory is that an electron can fall below ground state. That is supposed to be impossible according to wave based QM. That prediction was used to make another item that uses water and a bit of potassium to release from the water, about 200 times the energy that is in the same volume of gasoline. That has been validated by two physicists at Eindhoven Technological University and by several other validations. That validation will be in the journal Nature early in 2021. There will be a demo of the device in DC, on February 4, 2021.

That same theory was first used in 1986 by Herman Haus, an electronics engineering professor at MIT, to provide to the USA Department of Defence, a purely classlcal explanation for how the Free Electron Laser works. That uses a model of the electron that, in its free state, is a 2D disk consisting of several concentric rings of electric charge and a central pole of magnetic charge. That model can be seen in the first movie of an electron made by Lund University in 2008. Another prediction, made in 1995, was that the Universe's expansion is accelerating. That was corroborated by observations made of the CMBR in 1998 and in 2012. The theory was derived using first principles of Haus' non-radiation condition, Maxwell's electro-magnetism, the Stern-Gerlach experiment, Einstein''s Special Theory of Relativity, the deBroglie matter wave formulation and a few other bits that are well known and fully accepted by all physicists.

The resulting theory makes thousands of other predictions, many of which have also been corroborated or have eventually been slowly homed in on, such as constants that have taken decades to be agreed on, as being the same values as were arrived at by the derivational method used for this new theory, mostly by Mills himself.

When people explain the double slit experimental results, invariably light is depicted as sine waves drawn on paper. From there, superposition is explained. But, and it's a big 'but' - a huge proportion of the population believe that the Y-axis of the sine waves drawn on the paper is distance. I.E. that light waves physically move up and down in space - like waves on the surface of water or waves created when you shake a rope that's fixed at one end.  Since you can easily demonstrate the double slit result using a water tray, some barriers and some wave making vibrating elements, the jump is made straight to 'oh, that's what light is doing with the really close together slits'. But it is not the same.  When you use the sine wave diagram on paper to depict light travelling through space the units of the Y-axis is not distance measured in meters or inches but electric or magnetic field  measured in Newtons per coulomb or amps per meter.  Why electrical and magnetic FIELDs are affected by having light pass through two narrow slits is not really explained.

Luz é uma onda eletromagnética visível.
O frio é uma onda eletromagnética tangível assim como calor.
Creio que o odor também seja uma matéria tangível.

As ondas eletromagnéticas que não podemos ver tocar ou ouvir sentir,ver etc...carregam partículas muito leve em uma velocidade tremenda.

Sem o fósforo do TRC por exemplo,não poderíamos ver o feixe de luz branca que vai em direção ao vidro.

Então com alguns receptores super sensível poderemos interceptar essas ondas eletromagnéticas invisíveis.

Uma onda eletromagnética é uma matéria tem peso,velocidade,comprimento e amplitude.
Está sujeita assim como imã a ser atraída por uma outra onda eletromagnética mais leve do que ela.
Quer dizer no imã pólos contrários se atraem,pois bem para se atrair uma onda eletromagnética super leve e fina é preciso criar uma tanque ressonante super sensível.

Creio que podemos fazer isso verificando a capacitancia do tanque ressonante.
Pelo menos usamos o capacitor variavel para interceptar o canal de uma onda composta.

Pois bem,para você interptar uma onda no ar você precisa saber o peso de sua massa.


Para os átomos nitrato se ligarem precisam de um peso ideal.
Então o nitrogênio desse átomo de nitrato ,sua massa difere completamente da molécula de amônia por exemplo.


Sendo a onda eletromagnética uma massa.
Tem que está na mesma lei do imã e dos átomos.

Segundo Ruterford um átomo de urânio libera de ondas diferente.

Pois bem,é composta por três tipos de1 amplitude de 2frequência e de 3comprimento.
1 massa
2 velocidade
3 alcance


A luz branca do CRT também é composta por 3 ondas eletromagnéticas visível são elas:
Vermelho,verde e azul.
Temos aqui 3 velocidade distinta para formar uma composta.

Macho e fêmea e filho?

Eu sei que essa luz branca composta em 3 tipos de velocidade distinta.
Atravessando um difracao de uma grade com 600 fendas poderemos obter as 7 cores do arco-íris.

Neste último caso conseguimos refinar ainda mais o branco composto anterior.
Dividimos as três cores composta agora em 7.

Se juntassemos essa 7 cores novamente passando por um prisma iríamos para o branco denovo.


A verdade é que essas 7 cores visíveis tem velocidade.

Qualquer onda eletromagnética invisível deveria se comportar como as cores visíveis depois de lançarmos elas em difracaoes distintas.

Vamos supor no caso de Ruterford que percebeu 3 ondas eletromagnéticas no urânio.
Vamos dizer que ele viu apenas o vermelho,o Verde e o azul.

Lançando uma difracao teríamos um composta invisível formando algo parecido com o branco.
Lançando esse branco em outra difracao pela grade de 600 fendas teríamos agora as 7 ondas eletromagnéticas invisíveis.

Why did he say that light is not particle only wave? He is wrong.

It was a matter of great interest for scientists of know that what exactly from the light is made up of or how the light behaves.
Newton was the first scientist who said that light is made 0 up tiny elastic particles called "Corpuscles" which travels with the velocity of light. So according to Newtons, light is a particle.
Huygen was a scientist working parallel to Newton who come with a drastically different idea for nature of light & said that light is not a particle but a wave.
During the time of Huygen, his views regarding nature of light were not accepted as newton was a popular scientist of his time. but, when maxwell asserted that light is a electromagnetic wave, scientists started believing that light is a wave.
Once again when scientists started believing that the light is a wave max plank came with different idea & asserted that light is not a wave but a photon (i.e. a particle) which he proved through balck body radiation spectrum. At this time there was a great confusion about the nature of light which was solved by de-broglie from where origin of theory of matter wave come into picture.
supports dual nature of light (wave nature and particle nature). According to him the light consists of particles associated with definite amount of energy and momemtum. These particles were later named as photons.

The comparison with waves from two balls in a pond is not quite correct. If you shine light using two separate flashlights (or lasers, or whatever), you will not see any interference. Photons, like any other type of particle, do travel kind of like waves but only interfere with themselves, not others. It's basically as if every individual photon had its own pond all to itself. The interference only occurs when individual photons have two available paths (the two slits). In that case, the probability waves of that particular particle go through both slits and interfere with each other so that the particle is more likely to land in some places rather than others. If you send the photons (or electrons) one by one and record where they land, you will see individual dots for all the separate particles but when you put all those dots together, the bright bands appear. Each individual particle is simply more likely to land in the bright bands, because that's where the individual probability waves lead them.

If you have a few hours, watch Richard Feynman explain this in his famous "QED" lecture: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P9nPMFBhzsI. He does an excellent job of explaining everything in a way anyone can understand (much better than I can). It's interesting, funny, easy to follow, and the clearest and most exact explanation I've ever seen or heard.

Dualism and why it will never see the reality of dependent origination, and that there is neither a wave or a particle, nor a location, rather, just the apparition of such, to a conscious observer, or instrument of measurement; German physicist Werner Heisenberg developed the first equations of quantum mechanics using Matrix mathematics. He deduced that space and time were pixelated into indivisible, 3-dimensional Planck length units (similar to the 2D pixels on your computer screen). The mathematics indicated this, and there was no solid experimental evidence for smooth – in other words not pixelated – spacetime.
Smooth spacetime comes with the strange implication of an infinite amount of points between any two points. The entertaining Zeno’s Dichotomy Paradox confronts this problem by suggesting that if you want to get from point A to point B, you first must get half way between those two points. And to get there, you must get half way between those two points and so on ad infinitum.
Obviously, this paradox is silly because we usually do get to point B. however, if we do get to point B, this implies that reality is pixelated. Heisenberg’s ideas of a pixelated reality were too radical for most scientists of his day except, notably, for Niels Bohr, who agreed with them. Today, more scientists agree with this digital physics notion of a pixelated spacetime. Many still do not, and believe spacetime is smooth, and without structure – not pixelated. On the other hand, most agree that a length can be no shorter than the Planck length, which suggests that reality is pixelated. So there is a good deal of confusion.
I believe, that until a powerful quantum gravity theory of pixelated spacetime is discovered, the issue will remain confusing.

This will confuse you and has confused scientists to this day.

Scientists have proven that light is a particle. (Just look up "photon" and "photoelectric effect" on google)
The thing is, it acts as a wave; until you observe it at a quantum level. As soon as scientists started observing the light to see what particles went into what slit, the particles immediately started acting like a particle, where you could see only two beams at the end. As soon as they stopped observing it at a quantum level, they acted like a wave and created multiple beams.

So in a nutshell, light is a particle that acts like a wave unless observed at a quantum level.
Also, I learned this in my 8th-grade science class. (I might be a little off on the explanation, as it has been a while since I learned this.)

#1 Say: you have a field of many dimensions.: you mathematically manipulate the whole field to be represented in one dimension: you move a particle through the field: The particle will show up up intermittently in the single dimension: the single dimension is "packed" with directions the particle does not take: Field has X,Y,Z,I, C,M coordinates. one dimensional representation would be "packed" say XYZICMXYZICMXYZICM : For simplicity say the particle is only moved in the X direction : The particle would only show up in the x packets and skip the other packets: Is it easy to see a wave function with angular momentum developing out of this?
# 2 Say: I have two fields with two dimensions each,. [FS] and [FT]. Each field has a "static" and an "active" direction at 90 degrees to each other. [FS] & [FT] align static axis with active axis ie at 90 degrees to each other: The fields are pretty local:
# 3 Say: A particle is accelerated in a line towards a screen: a moving particle collapses the fields to one dimension creating a two dimensional plane(simplified) : The particle moves along the [FS] active axis in [FT] static time: The particle exists somewhere along the one dimensional [FS] active line depending on how the the field has been "packed": The particle while moving along the [FS] active axis is also moving along the [FT] "static" axis so no time occurs. The detector stops momentum and "collapses " the field back into its multi dimensions and the particle appears on the detector:
# 4 Say: the double split causes the plane to "flip". The [FS] static/ [FT] active axis is now aligned between the gun and the detector : The particle does not (???) along the The [FS] static/ [FT] active axis but time exists: The [FS] "active" / [FT] static axis is aligned parallel to the detector. The detector will "collapse" the [FS] active / [FT] static axis to all its dimensions: Assuming the packing of dimensions follows a function although each actual direction is packaged according to a probability function the particle appears on the detector as per wave function, gap, chance of particle, gap , chance of particle etc.

My idea is as follows :
The light at bottom of the box was not in shape of slits, but instead circular in shape because of diffraction through the aperture of slit, the edges of slit bend light waves in a way that they deviate from their actual path and form blurry circles;
It is according to Rayleigh's Criteria that when two maxima almost coincide we cannot differentiate between its images and it is not "resolved".Due to this many rays of light coincide at slit points and thus form one image that is blurry as explained. It is due to the resolution power of our eye that we are able to see so many points that are lit up.

Surprisingly enough, I heard that the double slit experiment is outdated, because new data is available. The "wave patterns" we see are supposedly produced by different sources of radiation, even in a lab environment. As far as I know, even infrared radiation is enough to alter the path the Photons take, and even their interactions with everything else. I think I've seen a video, where the double slit experiment was set up nicely, but the results varied too much, because tiny amounts of heat are created by blasting the Photons in there, heating the environment up (enough to be detectable in the infrared range) - So at first, a particle characteristic was detected, but as soon as things have heated up enough, the wave patterns started to form as well.

To be clear here, with "heat", I'm also referring to the heat from the tools/computers/sensors you use, and that can apparently influence the outcome dramatically.

Very thought provoking. So, at times light behaves like a wave. In the wave concept, through what sort of medium does this wave propagate? Space-time as a construct helps explain more of what we observe. Still, is light carried primarily via raw space-time in what we colloquially refer to as the vacuum of deep space?

I suspect what we observe in this duality called light may be as much a function of the nature of space-time as a medium as it is anything else. The way a wave propagates or the way a particle passes through something often describes the medium in ways not otherwise observable. Relativity struck at the interrelationship of light and space-time and yet I can't help but think quantum investigation will be what takes us farther into it.

I will meet two classmates in a month for our 50th high school reunion. She, he, and I did the two balls on a water-light table. From the angles you can compute the wavelength. Then we let light through a slit, and impinged it on two slits, the resulting light-dark bands projected  on the wall allowed us to calculate the wavelength of light. I’m not 100 percent sure, but I believe the bright spots are not in the shape of perfect slits because between the bright spots there has to be a transition from total constructive interference to total destructive interference. Our eyes interpret this as the intensity of the light transitioning to zero as opposed to a sudden drop which would look like perfectly shaped slits.

The fraction of the incident light transmitted by various narrow slits of finite depth and with metal walls is measured for two states of polarization and two wave-lengths of the incident light. It is found: (1) that real, narrow slits do not transmit all the incident light; (2) that the transmission losses increase when the depth of the slit is increased, and decrease when the conductivity (or reflectivity) of the slit walls is increased; (3) that when a slit is more than about half a wave-length wide, light polarized with its electric vector parallel to the slit is transmitted better than light polarized with its electric vector perpendicular to the slit, and that for either state of polarization the fraction of incident light transmitted increases as the wave-length is decreased; (4) that a slit less than half a wave-length wide transmits light polarized with its electric vector normal to the slit only, and that in such a slit the fraction of incident light transmitted increases as the wave-length is increased. It is shown that the existence and order of magnitude of all these effects may be predicted from the electromagnetic theory of light, and that some of them may be expected from a consideration of the older scalar wave theory. Ref: https://royalsocietypublishing.org/doi/abs/10.1098/rspa.1954.0191

Foton bir ışık kaynağından bir saniyede milyarlarcası fışkıran ışık demetleridir. Işık ışınlarıdır, ışık partikülleridir. 

Şimdi bu ışınların oluşmasına beraberce bakalım. Başlangıçta bir takım nesnelere elektrik enerjisi verdiğiniz zaman o nesnelerde, o madenlerde veya gazlarda karşıt elektronların devir hızı, elektrik enerjisinin o elektrondan geçmesi sırasında; karşıt elektronların devir sayısı elektronlardan daha hızlı olarak artmaya başlıyor. Tungsram gibi bir takım madenler bu özelliği taşıyor. Bir de flüoresan lambaların içindeki gazlar.

Şimdi ne oluyor? Karşıt elektronların elektron sayısının yarısı olduğunu söylemiştik, devir sayısının. Basit bir rakam olarak vermek istiyorum. Diyelim ki bir elektronun devir sayısı saniyede 100 devirdir. Karşıt elektronun devir sayısı da bu durumda 50’dir. Elektrik enerjisi bölünmeye başladığı zaman bu söylediğimiz madenlerde karşıt elektronların devir sayısı hızlı bir şekilde artmaya başlar, elektrondan daha hızlı. Bunu da basit bir rakama bağlayalım. Diyelim ki öylesine hızla artıyor ki 200 değere vardığı zaman 50 değerlik bir elektron, karşıt elektron 50 devir sayısından 200 devire ulaştığı zaman 100 devirlik elektron da 200 devire ulaşsın. Ne olur? İkisi de eşit devir sayısına sahip olur. Bunun  mânâsı, hem devir sayıları eşittir hem de ağırlıkları eşittir. İşte fotonun oluşmasındaki iki temel unsur vücuda gelmiştir.

1- Elektron devir sayısı ile karşıt elektron devir sayısı aynı olmuştur. 
2- Elektron ağırlığı ile karşıt elektron ağırlığı da aynı olmuştur ama birinin ağırlığı negatif, birinin ağırlığı  pozitif.

Şimdi bütün bu elektrik enerjilerinden çıkan ışınlar normal standartlarda “gama fotonu” adını alıyor. Böyle bir gama fotonunu bir kurşun duvara vurdurduğunuz zaman anormal bir şey oluyor. Kurşun duvara vuran bir gama fotonundan bir tane elektron çıkıyor ortaya. Elektronun çıktığı yerden 180 derece farklı istikamet yönünde ikinci bir nesne daha ayrılıyor ve ikinci nesnenin ne olduğu dünyamızda henüz bilinmiyor yani bilmeyenler bilmiyor. O nesne elektronun karşıtı istikametinde hareket ediyor. Parlak ışık saçtığı için derhâl görülüyor ama belki bir saniye, belki saniyenin 1/100’i kadar bir zaman parçasında görünen bu ışık saçan nesne kayboluyor gözden. 

Şimdi bu foton, kurşun duvara vurduğu zaman oradan çıkan nesnenin bir tanesinin elektron olduğu kesinlikle tescil edilmiş durumda. Elektronun ağırlığı da belli. Şimdi konunun ilginç yanı şu ki, bugüne kadar yapılan bütün ölçümlemeler şunu göstermiştir ki gama fotonları ağırlıksızdır yani sıfır ağırlıklıdır. Şimdi Lavoisier kanununa göre hiçbir şey kaybolmaz, yoktan da var olmaz. İyi de buradaki denklemi yerli yerine oturttuğumuz zaman birisine A diyorsanız, elektron ağırlığına A diyelim ötekinin de bir pozitif ağırlığının var olduğunu zannediyor dünya ilmi ve ona da diyelim ki B tahmini değerini koyuyorlar. Elektron ağırlığı kesin bir ağırlık. Ötekinin de kesin bir ağırlığı olduğunu kabul eden bizim fizik âlimleri burada şaşırıp kalıyorlar. Çünkü 0= A + B oluyor. A’nın ağırlığı kesin, B’nin ağırlığı imajiner, ne kadar olduğu bilinmiyor. Ama en azından pozitif ağırlığı olduğu kabul edildiği için  ‘A+...’  ne kadar hafif olursa olsun bir değer var. 

Öyleyse ‘A + B’ kadar bir ağırlıkla ‘0’ hiçbir zaman birbirine eşit olmaz. Çünkü A’nın elektron ağırlığı kesin olarak tespit edilmiş durumda. Oysaki olay ‘0 = (+A) + (-A)’ şeklinde. Ne çıkar ortaya? Eksi ağırlık (-A)’nın ağırlığıyla, (+A)’nın ağırlığı; birisi negatif ağırlık, birisi pozitif eşit ağırlıklar olduğu için birbirini götürürler.

You absolutely missed the amazing part of that experiment. For everyone who'd like to read about it I will shortly explain it as best as I can:

Light is made from, what people call Photons . Once scientists found light to have wave- and particle-characteristics, they wondered even harder what Light actually was. A wave? A particle? It can't be both, can it? To clarify they would shoot single Photons at that double slit and determine where and in what shape these would hit the sensor placed behind it. Take a break and think about what you would expect to happen.

Here comes the first paradox: The photons showed up at the screen as small dots and not as the result of interfering waves like they did before, which seems to prove that they are particles. However, when repeating the same experiment many times the points of impact of the individual photons would form the same wave pattern as before. That means that the single photon must have behaved just like a wave, traveling through both slits to interfere with itself.
That left the scientists even more clueless. How can something that obviously hits the screen in form of a particle behave like a wave just before? How is it determined where the photon will hit? What would determine wether the photon behaved like a wave or like a particle? Can a single photon actually form a wave and travel through both slits?

To answer these questions they build two sensors that would determine through which slit the photon would travel. When they repeated the experiment the individual photons always either traveled through the right or through the left slit and never through both. But something else changed aswell. When repeating the experiment many times and overlaying the points of impact they would no longer show the wave pattern. They would just show two stripes. The stripes that most people expected from the beginning anyways.

It is almost as if the photons knew they were watched and therefor behaved differently to not violate the laws of nature. Since then no one could find a satisfying answer to that paradox. But maybe, just maybe, you will have the groundbreaking idea?

That explanation doesn't work because when you send one electron in at a time the pattern still persists. Thus they can't just be interacting with each other.


And when scientists observed the experiment with a detector on one of the slits, that would go off as one particle passed through, suddenly the pattern became the expected two lines. Thus, the simple act of observation caused the electrons to act differently. This is proven. It is as if the electron knows that it is being watched. Because it defies logic when it makes the wave pattern, so when it is observed, it changes. When it isn't, it's the wave pattern.

It isn't magic, or the particles interacting, it's quantum mechanics. The results are there because we experimented in the first place. If we observe, results change, which seems not to make sense, but that's the point. But it has to, because it actually happens. We found the solution through quantum mechanics, something pretty damn complex.

Seeing this reminds me of a mirror. If you look into a mirror, you only see one reflection. But when you break that mirror in half, you get two reflections. Simply putting both edges of the mirror together does not merge the reflection back into one piece. However, if your mirror is convex or concave (as a wave would be) and you look at it, depending on the arc, you can get multiple reflections out of one solid piece. In this instance, Two can't equal one, but one can equal two. Such as in the double slit experiment, one wave split in two can make multiple, but putting multiple through one only makes one.

It makes sense, and it doesn't. How can one make two but two can't make one? Unless they cancel each other out, as the convex/concave mirror does if you continue to bend it.

Challenge at the end: White light from the sun is not monochromatic (ie it is made up of multiple colours). When the white light passes through the slits, each individual colour is diffracted by a different amount and each colour forms its own sets of fringes. The further out along the edges, the more space there is for the colours to seperate and appear as indidual bands which is why the middle bands are less fuzzy then the edges.

Sunlight is a mix of photons traveling at mixed polarities and mixed frequencies. The wavy behavior you observe is an artifact of quantum mechanics, that boils down to random uncertainty of the of how the light acts when it passes close to a slit border. This results in a probability distribution of light, that then adds up with the light from the other slit, making up the observed interference pattern. (Photons don't really interfere, it is just called an interference pattern). To summarize, light is particles, but their behavior can be confused, and often explained with wave theory.

Light can also be a particle.  And also you have different types of light.  For example. Some photon particles don’t emit visible light until they collide with other particles. So you could have an invisible beam of light, that only becomes visible after it collides with something else. In other words, the source of the light is not visible, but the surface those photons are reflecting off of, is visible. This happens in outer space often. Then you have energy waves that can emit visible light. This can be observed under a hydraulic press with certain materials. Under all that stress, when the item finally breaks under the pressure, sometimes you can see visible light coming from the point of failure. That sudden release of energy can emit light waves. So light, is not a black and white topic.  There are several different types of visible light.

If you put some dye in the water and then make a wave you will see very clearly that the water particles do not move. A wave is the transfer of motion from one particle to another. Neither particles nor waves pass through the slit in the slit experiment. Dye placed in the water in front of the slit does not pass through the slit. make a wave on a rope and notice that if you let the rope wave pass through a slit, none of the rope passes through the slit, despite many waves appearing to pass, no rope fibres ever pass through the slit. The particles do not move forward during wave motion.

Actually, light has particle duality, which means that light can act as a wave and a particle. In the original double slit experiment, the scientists observed multiple wave interferences, but when they tried observing the photons themselves to see how they acted, the particles acted like as if golf balls were going through the slits. So to answer the question of what light is would make you incorrect, it is neither a particle or a wave, but it is both at the same time.

It doesn't change because your viewing it, it's because you created a circuit.

The ball/round shapes are because the sun is a ball, and that is your light source. Either that or it is because the slits are long and photons (not "waves") can enter at any point on the length of the slit, and as skinny as the slits are, the light can enter at either slit at a range of locations (albeit a narrow range of locations, literally, and no nerd joke intended) -- and the sun has a width and height to it, and light can enter from any of a range of locations and angles coming into the slits, so the light/photons entering into the slits is not coming into the slits from one uniform location, and you get a smeared image of the light's source, a blurry edged ball/circle/round shape projected to the back of the box.

Of course, photons act like waves, even though particles. Weird stuff.

Now, why the little slit -- or maybe a pin hole -- would give a projection of the image of the light source is kind of interesting. That box was virtually the same set-up used to view a solar eclipse, that is, a pinhole projector. HOW DOES THAT WORK? Like to see a video on that.

That's amazing. Sound works the same way, except it's with sound! Waves don't usually reflect when they strike other waves. Instead, they combine (like showed in this video but with sound waves). If the amplitudes of two waves have the same sign (either both positive or both negative), they will add together to form a wave with a larger amplitude. This is called constructive interference. If the two amplitudes have opposite signs, they will subtract to form a combined wave with a lower amplitude and sometimes canceling out completely as well. This is called destructive interference.

Sound travels in waves. You hear sound because waves hit your ear. Sound waves are similar to ocean waves (like again shown in this video).They both have a certain frequency. The frequency is measured in hertz, which is one cycle per second. One wave cycle is a complete wave; both the up half (crest) and down half (trough) are part of one cycle.

If we observe the difference in a wave, and a gun firing single projectiles. We see instantly that the gun fires from one precise location. Through an opening. The edges of the slit do not interfere with the gun. If we look at the wave front we see that it is large, it is not a single projectile.
Much like a picture of the outdoors on a sunny day, entering through a small slit in a shade, creates an inverted image. Just like a glass lens will create an inverted image. Because the solid material on either side of the slit, blocks most of the light from displaying a correctly oriented picture. So the light that gets through on an angle creates an inverted picture.

Now if we fired a gun at a slit or two slits, from multiple locations, rather than from a single point, then we would create the same pattern through the slits as a wave would. If we fired red bullets with the gun aimed at the slits but positioned to the left of being perpendicular to the slits, those bullets would end up on the right of the slits, on the target. And if we fired green bullets at the slits with the gun oriented to the right of perpendicular to the slits the green bullets would end up on the left side of the slits when striking the target.

Sincerely,

William McCormick

This would insinuate that the electrons are behaving like waves and interacting like the water on the pond, cancelling each other out and meeting the wall at different intervals. This scientifically makes no sense, as the matter creates a wave of probability, meaning that if they fire a single particle at the slits, it could go through either one, both, or neither of the two. FURTHERMORE, when the particles are observed at the slits, they create a simple two slit pattern on the wall, and 'refuse' to create an interference pattern. This is great but there is a massive amount of confusion about what light is and what color is. This video is only really relevant to what light is. Colors share different relationships with each other. The color blue is demonstrably not a wavelength of light, and there are many reasons to think this. The first is that colors have similarity properties that wavelengths don't have. The color blue is more similar to the color purple than the color yellow. These similarity properties are not shared by the properties of waves of light (supposing light is a wave or wavicle). The wavelength that corresponds with the color blue has no properties that make it more similar to the wavelength that corresponds to the color purple than the wavelength that corresponds with the color yellow. But we do know that what goes on in the brain when someone experiences the color blue is more similar to what goes on in the brain when someone experiences the color purple than what goes on in the brain when someone experiences yellow. Color is more in your head than out in reality. A second, and more obvious, reason is that you can experience colors in the absence of the corresponding wavelengths of light. You can have experiences of sounds and colors while sleeping without the corresponding exposure to the wavelengths of light that normally cause you to have such experiences. The reason why is that the same events can happen in the brain from other causes. So, again, color is not the same as wavelengths of light. At best, color might be identical to types of brain events (but this has other problems). Even stranger, color might be non-physical all together.

With regard to the challenge at the end, light is a wave but it's a quantum mechanical wave, not an electromagnetic wave in the classical sense.  Light is composed of particles, which are described by wave functions that travel toward the slits, the wave function for each particle diffracts through the slits giving two sources for the same particle, which then interfere with one another to give an interference pattern for where they might arrive at the backstop, resulting in the pattern shown.  Light is made of particles, that have electromagnetic properties, and are best described by wave functions of probability for where they may be found.  The wave functions destructively interfere everywhere except for where the light spots are found.

I would expect a blur of light rather than just two lines of light, because ambient light doesn't just come from one direction, and it wouldn't travel through the slits in just one direction; it would head through them diagonally from a variety of angles, so of course you would get a blur, just as light travels through the pupil of the eye from various angles and hits the retina as a complete, upside-down, image of what the eye is looking at. Light from above heads diagonally down through the pupil and hits the bottom of the retina, light from below hits the top or the retina, light from the right hits the left of the retina etc. The same is true with a camera lens.

If you moved the back of that box closer to the slits the blurs would alter in size, and you might be able to focus them somewhat, just as a camera or an eye focuses the light it receives. It would be interesting to try it and see what happens, anyway.

I have several questions that I've wondered about in the past regarding the double slit experiment:

1) At what distance apart do the two slits behave as individual slits. Assumption: when the "bending" of light from one doesn't reach the bending of the other - but what if the overlap is partial?

2) At what width do the slits stop behaving as a "lens" and start behaving as a hole? Does this vary based on the distance to the other slit or the thickness of the material?

3) What about 3 (or more) slits? Do they react as individual sets or is there a combined effect? (obviously, the slits will need to be close enough for the outer slits to work in the same way that a double slit would work)

Have these questions been addressed in follow up experiments? I can intuit the "expected" answers but I believe that having these disproved may add further understanding to the overall behavior.

One procedure to begin the experiment:
- Use a similar setup, but place a graduated surface on the back so the widths of any image projected on it can be measured.
- Determine the minimum width for a single slit to produce an image. Record the width of the resulting image, and calculate the focal point based on the distance between slit and surface.
- Increase the slit width to twice as large, measure and recalculate the focal point - did it change?
- Create a second slit at a distance far enough away to have the images overlap by 50% (as nearly as possible), with the first slit covered recheck the position, image width, and focal point.
- Does the focal point change based on the combined image, indicating that the image has spread out farther than the individual slits?
- Do the troughs extend beyond the range of the overlapping portion?
- Add a third slit in the middle. Cover the left slit.
- Observe the pattern of the right two slits and compare the results based on the calculated focal point.
- Uncover the left slit.
- Observe the pattern of all three slits, and compare the image and impact to the calculated focal point.
- Extra effort: what if the slits were not equidistant in respect to the center slit? A ratio of 2:1, 3:1, or maybe the golden ratio?

The answers to most of these are probably obvious - but then again, with the obviousness of what should happen with the original experiment, there is good reason to investigate, don't you think?

Note: I believe that using a more consistent light source is needed to pursue these things because the variability of sunlight is likely to impact the results.

Here's your answer:
Each photon has its own electromagnetic field, equal in size to the frequency of its' "wave-length".
The edges of the slits also have fields of their own that overlap the fields of the photons as they pass through (similar to the eddy currents slowing a magnet dropping through a copper pipe), this pulls the photons toward the closest edge of the slit and propels them at their new trajectory, blurred by further interaction between each others' fields between the slit and the surface.
 
Those with a larger "wave-length" or, more accurately, a greater field-volume, spread at a different rate compared to those with a smaller volume, causing the end result to appear as if the photons were in fact waves, which they are on a smaller scale, but on any perceivable scale we have to work with, they're very much still what you'd consider physical.

Light (photon) is a particle.  As it moves it perturbs space and creates a wavefront that propagates away from it in all directions.  When the wavefront interacts with the slits the wave passes through the first slit but a part of it also continues to the second slit.  The waves recombine on the other side and form an interference pattern.  The interference pattern itself influences the motion of the photon.  As more photons  go through the slits the eventual pattern of bands appear.  It's a cumulative effect of particles creating waves which then influence the particles.

I think our world is like a giant vdo game where the begining and the end is pre-decided , to understand this please imagine that you are playing a call of duty game, whre the begining of the game, the road you have to walk on , number of enemies you come across, the bridges you will cross over, the types of weapons available to use to you and the ultimate mission of the game is already decided.. which means that the overall game is fixed but what is not fixed is how the user plays the game.. different players choose different paths to complete the game, some might choose to face the enemies (here enemies are our self assumed problems and difficulties which are avoidable) and some might chose to avoid the enemies and finish the game earlier without much difficulties, in both the cases, the user can complete the game but differently and the outcomes of his game are formed accordingly as per the choices he makes..

now lets try to understand this from the perspective of double slit experiment.
the experiment says that the electron is present everywhere until an observer (a choice maker) makes a choice to see it, likewise in our vdo game, the user can choose any path to finish the game, either by going on the same path he went on previously and kill the same no. of enemies or without crossing the bridge he previously crossed and finish the game..which means that the ways of finishing the game are many, but he sees only that path, bridges, enemies what he choose to see,i.e. they all are already there but not visible, but when an observer decides to see them then they appear at particular place..had he chosen different path his reality would be different, the time and the manner of finishing the game would be different..but the whole act of his choice made the one possibility among thousands of possibilities come to existance..he could see the road, bridges, enemies only because he chose to see them, had he chosen differet path this time, the time and the manner of finishing the game would have been different though the ultimate mission is same with various possibilities..

It is interesting that in the 200+ years since Young conducted the experiment, nobody ever thought to examine whether the pattern was in fact due to interference, until very recently. A recent paper in Physics Essays seems to show that it is not. For example, you can block the light emerging from one slit and still see the pattern on the other side, so convergence is not required. The circles were produced as an effect of a waveform on a 3 dimensional plane rather than a 2 dimensional plane as in water. In water the rarefractions are single points moving across a plane viewed from a top perspective but instead of forming a body of a circle, it produces single points where water meets up. In a 3 dimensional space, these positive interference points are actually due to the light coming in through a slight but still existentant third axis as depth in the points still exist. This is centered due to the fact that light doesn't only come in the left and right of the box but also through the top and bottom at different intervals. Since the sun isn't a single point in space and is also diffused into the atmosphere, the slits aren't ever hit at a perfect angle. There's no perfect slit representing the box. There's light coming from all different kinds of angles and with the rarefractions from the left and right edges of the slit there's also rarefractions from the top and the bottom aswell but not in the same manner. This is due to the concept of funneling. Not necessarily the diffusion of light waves but the actual concept of how when there's a source from not a singular point but instead a multi dimensional plane that when passed through a significantly smaller opening, the slit, and displayed with distance that the majority of the point will be centered. For example, take a sheet of graph paper and start with five dots on the top and go down ten spaces and five dots on the bottom. Sort of like this:
.....

.....

Now connect all of those dots in a manner of the first row to the second row. Light doesn't travel straight down. So you want to connect EVERY dot on the first row with EVERY dot on the second row. Now take two of your fingers and place them across in the middle like this:
. . . . .


--* *---

. . . . .
The rays that your fingers cover up are the slit, or the opening. Although, depending on where your fingers are, light will end up hitting every single other point; each point furthest distance from the center will have less light waves coming through because the angle at which they have to is significantly increased. This shows up as a circle in on a two dimensional plot due to the fact that all of the light in the rarefractions that are already their are split amongst a space in a vertical dimension aswell and allowing light to funnel in. On a plane, a single point spread out displays a circle.

The formation of dots involves the concept of Heisenberg uncertainty principle ...light other than  being an electromagnetic wave light is also a stream of photons now what happens is as this stream of photons approaches the double slit which has a really narrow opening the uncertainty in momentum increases due to decrease in uncertainty of position (due to narrowness of the slit) this tends to release particles with  great momentum from the narrow opening and hence they tend to hit the surface of the wall with least uncertainty in the position and hence they form a dot which has the least surface area...

Light has no intrinsic behavior as a wave or particle, in fact photons don't move. Proof: In the delayed choice experiment, IF information regarding a photon's trajectory exists THEN a particle pattern appears, however IF the trajectory is unknowable, THEN it produces a wave pattern. The wave pattern indicates that both slits are traversed simultaneously by the photon, which is impossible. Since the quantum is the minimum unit of information possible which could be introduced into the system (universe), and since the the patterns are observable by anyone anywhere in said universe, the delayed choice experiment is proof that absolute motion is an illusion and that reality is a self processing hologram where space, time, matter, & motion are the output phases of reflexive self-processing. Any counter-argument presuming absolute motion effectively states the particles do things like traverse both slits simultaneously, or go backwards in time to change course. The Quantum Zeno Effect resolves into a similar analysis. Bottom line: science has proven that reality is a fully self contained & self processing information system. Ok I'm at 1:04, the answer has not been given.. I'm just gonna put my answer here to see how close I am... I'll probably end up writing all that I know about light :/

Light is our representation of photons (aka electromagnetic waves) that enter our eyes, in frequencies between 400 THz (red) and 789 THz (violet). These frequencies are what set the boundaries of the light that we can't see, which is infrared (below the frequency of red), and ultraviolet (above the frequency of violet).
Our eyes only detect red, green and, blue, and then it just guesses what color we are seeing when it's in between. The light on an object is the light that it DOESN'T absorb, so for example, a yellow ball absorbs all the frequencies of light except for the color yellow. Then when it reaches our eyes, our brain says, "Oh, well I can't see this light, but it is exactly between the frequency of red and green, so it MUST be yellow."

That's all I can think of off the top of my head, feel free to add on to this...

This isn't even the really fantastic bit about the double slit experiment! You want to really blow peoples minds, if you use a photon beam and shoot one photon at a time at the double slit, you still end up with the interference pattern. Think of it as if you were shooting one bullet at a time at a concrete wall with two slits in it, and on the other side, you ended up with multiple lines of bullet marks in stead of just two lines of bullet marks, this is what happens with light as well. This is due to the theory of "wave / particle duality" each photon of light takes every possible path (an infinite number of paths) to the wall of double slits and threw at the same time and interferes with itself, in this regard it is both a particle and a wave at the same time. This has been proven true and is an integral part of the theory of quantum mechanics and is what gives us the idea of quantum states. There is a kicker here, if you slow down each photon of light and track its position as it travels to the double slit, you will see it hit the wall like you would normally think, the simple fact that you have observed it, causes it to "behave normally".

The reason why we see points instead of lines is because the Heisenberg uncertainty principle went into action. The Heisenberg uncertainty principle says that if you know better the position of a particle, then you will know worse its momentum <del>and therefore the direction of its velocity</del> and vice versa. To make sure that your double slit experiment works, I can imagine that you had to settle down the slits with a width comparable to the wavelength of visible light, so since you are forcing sunlight beams go through such a small space (and thus reducing the uncertainty in the position of that light beam) the uncertainty in the momentum has to grow up leading to a hazy like light beam path.

I'm shocked that the most mind blowing aspect of the double slit wasn't even mentioned in passing in the video.

When you introduce a device at each slit that detects a photon as it passes through the slit, the wave properties of light disappear and you get what instinct tells you - two illuminated slits on the far surface. So just by introducing a measurement, light ceases to act like a wave and instead acts like a particle.

There's tons to read on the subject and it's all fascinating. But explaining the double slit without so much as a mention to this amazing quantum property just doesn't seem satisfying.

the photon moves linear, but has a wave like movement visible only in a higher dimension.

If you looked at it from a higher dimension it would be a wave and a linear motion at the same time.

In our dimension we only see it move linear with the slit experiment you can see its wave like element. The interaction as a projection from a higher dimension.

As an analogy, if you looked at the path of the photon from the top, you see a line.
If you look at it from the side, you see a wave. Now extrapolate that to 3d space and the wave is one dimension above what we perceive as 3 dimensions.

In that sense, a photon when measured has always the same intensity but a changing position in higher space. Do two photons meet, the relative position in the higher dimension come into play and add up or even cancel each other out.

Is light a particle or a wave is the WRONG question.  That is why it CANNOT be answered.  Light (and electrons too) are very interesting probability waves which collapse down into a particle.   The real question is what are the attributes of a probability wave.  From what I know it contains some form of an algorithm that causes its particle to collapse at some location and it has energy associated with it because when it collapses into a particle energy is measured.  The probability wave BECOMING a  particle process is the underpinning of the Heisenberg uncertainty principle.   The 2 slit experiment is the demonstration of what I propose.

When I first saw this experiment, I wanted to make a computer that used light for it's logic.  All of the logic used in a computer reduces down to just two things, the ability to add something together (OR-ing) and especially the ability to invert something.  Or what you really need is some medium that you can invert.  The double slit directly inverts light if you measure it at a position just off the center bright band in a dark spot.  So if you keep one slit lit all the time you will see light at that spot, but if you light the second slit, you get darkness at that spot.  That's an inversion, and it's what you need to create logic that runs at the speed of light with now mechanism other than the slit.  The first thing I would do is use mirrors to tie the output to the input and see if it oscillates at the speed of light, although I don't know how I would measure that, so the second thing I would do is set up a series of gates that forms a latch and see if I could create a bit of memory - that would be visible.
