I am a big fan of Veritasium, thank you for creating this video. 

To begin with I am not an authority on this subject nor do I entertain the idea I know more than the brilliant minds of the scientific community. What I can state is I am an autodidact with a passion in the pursuit of the truth of light.  For the last three years I have been working in the field of solar power research. The questions I entertain daily are: What is light? How do we define it? Once it is "defined" how will that definition help serve Humanity? 

My perspective is there is no right or wrong answer, my intention is to understand what light is and maximize its potential in technology. From my experiences the challenge with the means and methods of empirical evidence is can I trust my eyes to guide me to the definitive answer? Is light a phenomenon that specifically stimulates the rods and cones in the back of my retinas? Or is light far more expansive and diverse in nature? And am I limiting my understanding of light through visual interpretation alone? 

Here is an experiment that offers us another experience of "light". Close your eyes and apply firm pressure with your fingers onto both eyes for two minutes, what happens? Within a minute you will begin to see contrasting patterns emerging. Is this light? Neural impulse interactions? What could this be? How do I explain with my eyes closed that even in the "darkness" emerges contrasting patterns of light and dark?

Other considerations are the many optical illusions that "trick" our eyes into "seeing" something, but in fact is skillfully crafted to be something entirely different. Many a magician profit wondrously from optical illusions. So if we understand our visual interpretation can be tricked than how do we know the double slit experiment is a “true” observation or an optical illusion?

More on the limitations of the double “slit” experiment, for now let’s review the ideas light as a wave, particle or wave/particle sandwich.

First challenge, the observation of the wave.

An analogy early scientists have utilized to describe light are through the observation of the undulating patterns of the surface tension of water. We observe wavelike patterns when we interact with the surface tension of this liquid. And have adopted words like "interference patterns" and "cancelation" between the interactions of peaks and troughs to define the observations. What I question is how is it that we can assume a sine/cosine function relative to fluid dynamics is also a means to define the behaviour of light? I am not questioning the physics of this observation, it is real, it has its place, but who made it the definitive conclusion light behaves like water? Again comparing peaks and troughs, sine/cosine functions. So we are saying light can be thoroughly defined by a rise and fall on a x and y axis? Really? Come on!!!

Second challenge, the theory light is a “particle”. 

I state theory because a particle is a word loosely defined by science. Defined as a small localized object primarily utilized effectively in the world of physical and chemical properties. I am in total agreement in its usage, however to define “light” as a particle is in my humble opinion, an assumption. I won’t bore you with the history of photovoltaic process other than it was documented around 1839 and has remained a curiosity of many brilliant minds ever since.

In my experiences studying the photovoltaic effect for a number of years I can state we are still in the infancy of truly harnessing the power of the sun. Why? Due to the uncertainty of what light is. How is it the major bodies of science have varying opinions on the nature of light and yet have the ability to create “standards”. For example the standard that Sunlight on its best day on Earth produces 1000 watts per square meter. Amazing how the “Sun” gave us such a wonderful round number of 1000! Wonderous, thank you Sun for keeping it so simple! :-)

When we truly understand the nature of light a technology exposed to one hour of Sunlight will power entire cities. Yes call me crazy, and embracing the hidden dangers of optimism, but seriously folks modern science defines the photovoltaic “event” as:

1.) The “absorption” of a photon creates an electron-hole pair.
2.) A minority carrier called a “hole” makes it across the junction, and becomes a majority carrier.
3.) After the hole passes through a load (e.g. a light bulb), the electron meets up with the hole and completes the circuit.

In layman terms a “photon” defined as a elementary particle, “knocks” electrons loose from a substance, for a brief moment the electron creates a “hole”, divorce papers are filed, mediation takes place with resistance (our load), a little bit of time living on their own the electron, and the electron hole start thinking about each other, listening to Michael McDonald’s song “I keep forgetting we’re not in love anymore”. They start to feel the pull to come back together, realizing the atomic dating scene is terribly complicated, and then magically they are back together… until another flat bellied electron home wrecker (aka the Photon) comes along and starts the whole process all over again. (ahem)

The wave/particle sandwich challenge, the Photon.

As already mentioned, that is (trumpets blaring), the Photon. The Photon previously described as an “elementary particle”. By its very definition is a convolution of terms. A logical approach to the semantics of this word phrase “elementary” meaning something simple and basic, and “particle” a word loosely defined by science. This then translates to Light as “a simple version of a particle.” I totally get it! Wow! Hmmm, nope I am more confused than ever….


I want to apologize to photovoltaic experts whom perhaps at this moment are contemplating preparing a very elaborate highly detailed explanation proving me wrong, and most likely state I’m an arrogant uneducated derelict who knows nothing of the photovoltaic process. I can accept that, you’re right, I’m not an expert nor do I have a degree in this field of science.

If I may ask why is it that in 1960 solar cell efficiency was 14%, 54 years (that’s fifty four years) later one sun solar cells have just recently achieved 19% efficiency? 

To the credit of multi-junction technology it is currently at 44%, however there are exorbitant costs to manufacture this technology.

But, I digress…

My intention with my rant is to offer an opportunity to humbly ask, what if the current definition of Light and the photovoltaic processes are inaccurate?

What if Science has yet to truly understand what light is, and has been struggling to improve a much needed technology to surpass the cost per watt barrier of coal, gas and oil?


Returning to the double slit experiment limitation.

Let us marvel at its genius, its simplicity, and awe inspiring method to observe a mind blowing visual phenomenon that leaves us more in the dark about light.

Science as we have come to understand it relates to the practice of documented observations of nature. Since the dawn of the written word itself curiosities of nature have been discussed, debated, and even plagiarized to obtain notoriety and stature. A new entertainment was born in the early societies as to what culture had the smartest nerds on campus. A political agenda emerged, and in some cases used as leverage to claim one society as “more advanced” than others. Offering the conclusion we are superior therefore have the right to declare we are at the top of food chain and you are the inferior species.

A moral corruption in science ran rampant in the 1800’s. Brilliant minds who were the true disciples of science were manipulated, ripped off by political tyrants of their time. Words were misinterpreted from their original meanings. For example the word electric from the Latin electricus was originally defined as “like amber” as described by English scientist William Gilbert. Even the Greek word “elektron” also referred to the material amber. Another Greek word “Atomos” defined as “indivisible”, and yet science continues to this day to dissect the atom into smaller and smaller “particles”.

This brief topic of history of science sets the stage for questioning the validity of the double slit experiment with the following question.

Why did Thomas Young make the assumption a “slit” would be the judge and jury to define light? 

Tell me where in Nature is there a naturally occurring straight line or rectangle for that matter? 

I am sure Euclid introducing his works “The Elements” was rolling in his grave when Sir Thomas Young made this assumption. That two small rectangles will define the nature of light.

In order to understand Nature we must learn to recognize the nature of Nature. 

We are literally hundreds of years off track from the misinterpretations of the nature of Nature. 

And what of women scientists? I am sure there were many brilliant women scientists who in my opinion have an innate relationship with Nature that man will never comprehend.

So where do we begin to answer this question what is light?

Let’s start with trees, and their highly efficient process of photosynthesis.

Let’s study the anatomy of the eye revealing there are no relationship to lines, mathematics, and the theory of “symmetry”.

Anyways, in the event you have made it this far I thank you.

I have a vision where Humanity is free from oil, gas and coal. 

That when we have looked deeply within ourselves to pursue the truth of the nature of light we will discover it is a personal journey for each of us.

Once enough brilliant minds come together who understand the nature of light, amazing solar technologies will emerge.

And please I beg you, in less you have personally experimented with light, and photovoltaics with your own eyeballs do not trust our predecessors and their “theories”.

Discover for yourself the Nature of light.

Light is a paradox. The design of the experiment determines whether the result shows it to be a particle or a wave. The Elders who demonstrated its' wave like characteristics were only able to prove that it was a wave- that is what their test showed. The most conclusive 'tests' to show its' particle characteristic have been conducted by Alain Apect and his crew in the 1970s.. The wave/particle paradox was the first iteration of the quantum paradox which was described and formulated by N.Bohr in his Copenhagen Interpretation during the 1920s. Its' particle nature is best demonstrated by its' ability to be 'counted' on a conduction pad- see Aspects results. There have been other tests to show that human eyes need approximately 7 photons per second to perceive "light". For more on this- Ch. 12, "Quantum Enigma", by Rosenblum and Kuttner.  a good read.

In understanding of modern quantum mechanics, a "particle" of light is nothing but a light wave that is highly concentrated at a place, so that it behaves like a particle. A spread-out wave can become concentrated through a process called "wave-function collapse", and thus behave like a particle. On the other hand, a concentrated wave (a "particle") can become a more spread-out wave by evolving with time according to the Schrodinger's/Dirac's equation. So the wave-particle duality, as usually described, is not really a duality. It's just waves of different types.

He skips the most amazing part about the double slit experiment.  The idea that light is a wave is indeed fascinating, but it doesn't stop there.  The most mind blowing thing about this experiment is if you have a device to detect which slit the photons go through, light behaves like a particle.  The act of measurement changes the behavior of light, or electrons, whichever one is used.  Somehow the act of detecting the particles collapses the wave into a single event.  If you think of the wave as dice, a particle is when the dice lands on a number.  It only lands on a number when you are watching it, otherwise it is 1 through 6 at the same time.

That woman was right, light is indeed an element. It's called Lumium. It's found in all materials and looks like a Hydrogen atom only it has a lone neutron for a nucleus instead of a proton. This makes it negatively charged and so it has a tendency to repel away from its source at high velocity and continuing until it bonds with another material. The hotter a material is, the more of these will be released and so the light produced will be brighter and of a higher wavelength.
    Like all elements, Lumium is affected by gravity and often clumps together in large groups, being slowly released over time. We call these clumps stars. Lumium has the same relative atomic mass and electron configuration as Hydrogen which is why people would mistakenly have you believe that stars are in fact made of that. But seriously, if that were true than stars would end their life as a huge cloud of steam. 
    Thermal radiation is also a myth based on common misconception surrounding Lumium. Things get warm when you leave them in the sun because Lumium starts to saturate an object and so has to diffuse more quickly to balance out the concentration gradient. This process of removing excess Lumium from an object is known as Illumination and is exothermic. This reaction is reversible and its opposite reaction, Lumination, is endothermic. This is why air higher up is colder. It has bonded with more Lumium from the sun and has absorbed more heat. Obviously further away from the source of light not only will less Lumium hit the object but much of it will bond with the air, reducing the concentration gradient between the object and its surroundings leading to a slower illumination process. The rate at which illumination or lumination occurs within a given material is referred to as its Luminosity. 
    The negative charge of Lumium is also why things tend to give you a shock if you touch them after they've been in the sun a while. In fact, electricity is simply the potential difference of Lumium between two points. When a current is produced in a wire Lumium constantly breaks and reforms bonds with the surrounding materials, which results in a net movement along the wire. This movement of Lumium can be amplified by increasing the amount of material in a given space, which is how electric motors and generators work. Obviously the breaking bonds produce heat which is why wires get hot when a current passes through them. Transition metals allow Lumium to travel through a wire much more smoothly than other elements, particularly Silver and Copper, and so these are used most often in wires.
    Light bulbs work by emitting Lumium from a wire filament very quickly. The filament is made of a Tungsten-Lumium alloy called Magnitudite and his surrounded by a highly concentrated inert gas: Argon Brightase. This gas replenishes the supply of Lumium in the wire but eventually it depletes all of its Lumium and the bulb blows. When a material has expended all of its Lumium it is known as having been Delighted. New proprietary technology known at LEDs, Lumium Emitting Diodes, work by absorbing Lumium from the air around it then emitting it again at a higher frequency. These last much longer and, because of the illuminated air that undergoes lumination and absorbs heat, produce less heat.
   So remember, light is an element, and we are all illuminating, so think about that next time you're feeling like you don't affect the world around you.

Since you obviously already know the answer to the question you asked at the end, it wouldn't make much sense for me to tell you, but I will say a bit here for the sake of anyone you left curious, without actually giving the answer away. A pin-hole camera does not need any lens to focus the light coming through the opening, because the opening is so small, but it also does not produce a very bright image for the same reason. If you make the hole bigger, you get a brighter image which is less focused. Since the hole is usually round and the sun is spherical causing any full image of it to be round, an image of the sun is a good way to experiment with why and how the image blurs with the use of a larger hole. In fact, try using a long thin hole, a square hole, a triangular hole, a "Y" shaped hole, and so on, and it should become very clear exactly what's happening which would cause the image in the experiment done in this video to look like "dots" or "blobs" rather than "slits" or "lines".

You end with “So convincing were the results of Young’s double slit experiment that the scientific community concluded …”.  You give the scientific community far too much credit.  It is a community which history clearly shows is bound by authority, orthodoxy, and convention.

Young delivered his findings in The Bakerian Lecture, “Experiments and Calculations relative to Physical Optics” and the transcript was reproduced in 1804 Philosophical Transactions (RS).  The Edinburgh Review or Critical Journal (Oct. 1804 - Jan. 1805.) had this to say:  “The paper which stands first, is another Bakerian Lecture, containing more fancies, more blunders, more unfounded hypotheses, more gratuitous fictions, all upon the same field on which Newton trode, and all from the fertile yet fruitless, brain of the same eternal Dr Young”.  This is representative of what the scientific community thought of Young’s work at the time.

The scientific community was only swayed to Young’s view after Augustin Fresnel’s paper “Memoir on the Diffraction of Light” was ‘crowned’ by the French Academy of Sciences in 1819.  At least you did sufficient research to know that ‘double slit’ is a misnomer for Young’s 1803 experimental work – “I brought into the sunbeam a slip of card …”.  However, in your written description of Young’s experiment you still persist with “onto two narrow, closely spaced openings”.  No, it was diffraction around the two edges of a thin card – no double slit!

"Light must be a wave. There is no way it could be a particle."
What about the photoelectric effect? Long-wavelength visible light (e.g., red light) at any intensity doesn't liberate electrons from sodium, but shorter wavelength light does. Changing the intensity of the light doesn't change the kinetic energy of the released electrons, but changing the wavelength does. Also, even very dim violet light produces electrons, but no matter how few these electrons are always of higher kinetic energy than liberated electrons from higher wavelength lights of higher intensity.

To put this simply, the only way to explain this effect of light is that light is carried by discrete particles of varying energy, and that energy is related to the colour of the light. Because the photoelectric effect exists, light must be a particle.
Of course, diffraction shows that light must be a wave. 

QED, light must have properties of both waves and particles.

At the end Derek states that scientists concluded that light must be a wave and that there is "no way it could be a particle".  But it can and it is.  Really it wasn't that the "light waves" passed through the slits but rather that the probability waves associated with each light particle (photons) passed through the slits and interfered with each other to give a probability distribution of where the photons might end up.  And this probability distribution dictates where the light spots show up.  I think the language in this film is at odds with the particulate solution for light.  Really cool demonstrations though and the quantum mechanical view might be kind of difficult to convey even though most physicists agree that's what going on.  So quantum mechanical waves instead of electromagnetic waves.  Particles with electromagnetic properties.

Your box is nothing more than a large, pinhole camera. A pinhole camera doesn't use a lens. It doesn't even need a perfectly round pinhole. It can work with a slit, too. When you look at the image in the box, you are looking at the sun, which is round. It's blurry, because you haven't found the correct focal point. Try it indoors, aimed at a lamp, the tv, or a window. When the image is focused, you won't see a dot of light. You will see the lamp upside down and backwards.

The rounded blobs of colored light at the bottom of the box are caused as a mix of 'vertical' projections of sunlight through the slits, and imaging of the sun's round shape as if with a pinhole camera. Doppler effects repeat this image pattern in a horizontal array.

Light behaves depending on how you measure it. The double-slit experiment shows the wave properties of light. There are other phenomena (e.g. photoelectric effect) which show its particle properties.
With one slit you will get a single elongated band (elongated along the axis perpendicular to the length of the slit) that disappears to the sides. This occurs when the slit's width is close to the radiation wavelength (see: watch?v=a8FTr2qMutA), hence the slits had to be very narrow in the video.
The reason the bright patches are circular and not slit shaped is that the wave fronts are always spherical, and their projection onto the plane (the box) is a circle.

Light does not actually "have" colors, it is our brain that creates the perception of color. What light have is wavelengths, and our brain creates an image in our heads that interprets those wavelengths as different colors. Our eyes have three types of color-sensitive cone cells, corresponding to "red", "green", and "blue", i.e. 570 nm, 540 nm and 440 nm respectively (exact definitions varies). The mixture of how active these cells are are interpreted by the brain as different colors.

You don't understand radiation. Radiation doesn't have to be a particle. You can only "see" objects because we sense light bouncing off of them. You really don't "see" objects, you only perceive light bouncing off of them or being created by them. Light is a form of energy, much like other forms of radiation with the exception of Beta and Alpha particles, which are, as you described, moving particles.

It is in essence a flow - kind of like a stream. The electrons are the water flowing in a little stream-bed which would be the atoms. This is also why you can't get electrical current with an open loop - it's much harder to force the electrons off their atoms if they have no replacements behind them. Also in this analogy we can explain static electricity as a charge gap - Think of a dam blocking water. On one side it is high, on the other it is low. When the dam breaks there is a surge -a spark.

Displacing electrons is not necessarily destructive. If you were to strip an electron from an atom it would merely become ionized. With some more unstable compounds this may be a problem, but most materials can handle some ionization.

As an example think of the electron displacement in a piece of copper wire. As some electrons from one atom are stripped and forced up-current, the atom down current sends its electron up current, and the atoms before it do the same, and before that, and so on.

Electric charge and current are, respectively, the density and flow of - appropriately enough - electrons. Electrical energy in the abstract may be a concept but it is one with physical backing.

If your critique of science is "Fucking magnets, how do they work?" I suggest you talk to a scientist, because they're most likely not lying, and hopefully you won't get pissed.

Also, Gamma Radiation is composed of high energy photons.

The solutions to the Shrodinger equation for free particles looks like a wave equation (a sinusoid) which is why particles can appear to have a wavelength. Actually light is neither a wave nor a particle (nor both).  It's a probability distribution according to quantum mechanics.  You can make light behave as a particle even with the double slit experiment by simply observing which slit each photon goes through.  Observe the photons and they will behave as particles, look away and they will behave as waves.  This is because the act of observation causes the wave function (probability distribution) to collapse to a single, particle-like state.

this phenomenon is called geometric optics. In short it's that light travels in straight lines. So if there is a tiny aperture, then light from the left side of it will pass through the hole and end up on the right, while light from the right side of the source will pass through and end up on the left. Same for the top and the bottom. So you will end up with a flipped, inverted image of the light source. This is how a pinhole camera works.

Particle-wave duality! Young's 2 slit experiment demonstrates light acting with wave properties shown by the interference pattern produced. However if you perform an experiment known as the photoelectric effect, UV light is shone onto a negatively charged zinc plate, you will observe the zinc plate discharging. Light doesn't act like a particle and wave at the same time. It acts (is) one or the other depending on the experiment and/or measurement being made. So light is either a wave or a particle. Similar to how the wave function of a coffee mug is zero (classical), but if you look at say an electron, it is not zero. (Quantum)

2) By same distance from ZERO - I mean the same distance from the original water line.  If there are two sources of waves, then they will interfere with each other.  If a peak meets with another peak, then the new combined peak will be a large peak. If a peak from one wave meets with the trough of another, they will cancel, and that part of the water will be as if no wave is there at all. This will create a distinct interference pattern which is what we see with this particular light experiment.

1)  Imagine a perfectly still lake. There is a distinct water line on that lake.  If you were to create a wave in that lake, some parts of that wave will be BELOW the original water line and some will be above it.  The LOWEST points on each wave (each wave has one since waves are repetitive) are called troughs.  The highest points are called peaks. (the are both the same distance from ZERO just opposite sides).

It is not true that mass is a property of something that is not moving. Things have a mass when they don't move, let's call this m0, and a relative mass when they move which is m0/sqrt(1-v²/c²).
OK, you can argue about whether photons have a mass or not, but you can assign a mass to a photon with m=h/(c*λ).
(m = mass of photon, h = Planck constant, c = speed of light, λ=wavelength of light)
So a photon of red light (620nm) has a mass of 3,6*10^-36kg

photons do not have mass.  They have energy.  If a particle is massless, then it travels at the speed of light (in a vaccuum).  It MUST travel at the speed of light.  It has no choice.  Massive bodies, on the other hand, obviously have mass and MUST travel SLOWER than the speed of light.  This notion you have that photons have no mass when they stop moving is completely backward from actual reality.  Mass is a property of something that is not moving.  If it has no mass, it will travel at c.

General relativity does not really prove that Isaac Newton was wrong.  General relativity just greatly elaborates on the theory of gravity.  All newton did was figure out how to calculate it. The equations do begin to break down when dealing with very large gravitational fields, but in general....general relativity does not prove Newton wrong.

Lightwaves are transversal waves of a magnetic and an electric field which means that the peaks and troughs form sine curves with the y-axis of each perpendicular to the direction of the beam, as you suggest. Interference is the effect of two waves "adding up" in their respective paths.

Diffraction is the effect of a wave seeming to bend, due to the phenomenon of interference.  Keyword is bend.  Diffraction is when the path of a wave bends in to what should otherwise be its shadow.
There is no reason for any polarization in this example.  It is a uniform mix of both "surfing" and "snaking" waves of light, much like sunlight always is.

here's my answer if you want: Light can be both particles and waves, it can assume *both* forms, but *never* at the same time! This is called a particle-wave duality: Things can behave as both. So what determines this? The short answer is: It depends on how you measure it. 
If you measure it as if it were a wave (/w interference tests), it'll behave as a wave. If you measure it as a particle (like with detecting photons individually), it will behave as a stream of particles.

Yes. It's very real. It's a measurement. It measures how matter moves though space. One of Earth's orbits around the sun is one year. One of Earth's rotation around its axis is one day. And hours, minutes and seconds are all smaller measurements of that same spinning. So an hour is approximately 1/24th of a rotation.

So, yes. Very real. But, like all measurements, a human construct created to help us understand our universe.

"This question was answered by Young's double-slit experiment."

No it wasn't. It's impossible to explain the photoelectric effect (and the Compton effect, etc.) with classical waves. Light is made up of quantum-mechanical particles called photons. They do not behave like classical particles, and cannot be explained in terms of anything familiar to you. They have associated wave-functions which provide the interference effect, but they are still particles.

The energy is simply "moved", not destroyed. Let's imagine 2 waves with the same amplitude collide (they have the same "height"), and they create areas of 50% constructive and 50% destructive interference (almost impossible, but I'm hedging for simplicity). The constructive zones will have twice the amplitude of the original waves, and the destructive is flat. The wave appears to be "transferred", but it remains the same 2 waves expanding from a center point. Hope that helps.

Photons ("packets" of light energy) act like particles, AND as wave functions in different scenarios. There are ways of getting them to behave almost exclusively as particles, and there are circumstances under which they behave almost exclusively as waves, such as the above experiment. The field of particle physics assumes that photons are particles and that works pretty well up to a point, then weird things happen that can only be explained as wave interactions.
